evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as per historical dynamic understanding prior to preliminary analysis.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists defeaters by consistently matching observed behaviors and evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident without contradictions.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and coordination lapses affecting crew performance.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as per historical dynamic understanding prior to preliminary analysis.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP despite communication attempts indicates a breakdown in coordination.
The presence of communication does not guarantee effective coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination with no observable breakdown or if the incident was caused solely by procedural deviation without coordination failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, but the pushback continued beyond the stop point causing a collision, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from coordination failure

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and coordination lapses affecting crew performance.

assumptions: Assuming that the trainee driver's request to stop and instructor's takeover reflect coordination issues and miscommunication affecting crew performance.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without lapses or miscommunication, or if procedural deviations better explained the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication between crew and headset operator, trainee driver requesting instructor takeover, instructor advising trainee, and aircraft movement beyond expected point, indicating miscommunication and coordination lapses consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the communication was sufficiently broken down or just procedural deviation; limited detail on exact communication failures.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical dynamic under test at time t0 preliminary phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must withstand potential counterarguments or evidence that could negate its significance in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA context at the given test phase.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational and safety parameters during the specified test phase.
